metadata.title: Heteropolyacid-based ionic liquids as effective catalysts for the synthesis of benzaldehyde glycol acetal

Heteropolyacid-based ionic liquids as effective catalysts for the synthesis of benzaldehyde glycol acetal Xiaoxiang Han a ⁎ Wei Yan a Keke Chen a Chin-Te Hung b Li-Li Liu b c Pei-Hao Wu b Shing-Jong Huang d Shang-Bin Liu b c ⁎ a Department of Applied Chemistry, Zhejiang Gongshang University, Hangzhou 310035, China Department of Applied Chemistry, Zhejiang Gongshang University Hangzhou 310035 China b Institute of Atom and Molecular Sciences, Academic Sinica, Taipei 10617, Taiwan Institute of Atom and Molecular Sciences, Academic Sinica Taipei 10617 Taiwan c Department of Chemistry, National Taiwan Normal University, Taipei 11677, Taiwan Department of Chemistry, National Taiwan Normal University Taipei 11677 Taiwan d Instrumentation Center, National Taiwan University, Taipei 10617, Taiwan Instrumentation Center, National Taiwan University Taipei 10617 Taiwan ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Academia Sinica, Institute of Atomic and Molecular Sciences, Taipei 10617, Taiwan. Tel.: +86 571 28008975/+886 2 23668230; fax: +86 571 2800 8900/+886 2 2362 0200. Graphical abstract Heteropolyacid-based ionic liquid catalysts with superior acetal yield, excellent durability, and unique self-separation property desirable for facile recovery and recycling during homogeneous conversion of biomass are reported. A series of environmental benign ionic liquid (IL) catalysts, synthesized by incorporating varied amounts of tungstophosphoric acid (TPA) and pyridinium propyl sulfobetaine (PPS) zwitterionic precursor, were exploited for homogeneous conversion of biomass. In particular, these water-soluble PPS-TPA IL ([PPSH] x H3−x PW12O40; x =1.0–3.0) catalysts were evaluated for acetalization of benzaldehyde with glycol. The catalyst system revealed self-separation characteristics, which resulted in the formation of biphasic product/catalyst layers to render facile product separation and catalyst recycling. Among various PPS-TPA ILs examined, the [PPSH]2HPW12O40 catalyst exhibited excellent durability and an optimal acetal yield over 85%, in good agreement with that predicted by factorial design of experiments and response surface methodology (RSM). The effects and correlations of different experimental variables such as reaction time, relative reactant concentration, amount of water-carrying agent, and amount of catalyst were addressed by the Box–Behnken design (BBD). The deduced optimal conditions lead to an acetal yield of 85.2%, which is consistent with experimental results and that predicted by the BBD model. The superior acetalization activities observed for the novel PPS-TPA IL catalysts are attributed to their highly acidic nature and weak mass transport resistance. Keywords Heteropolyacids Ionic liquids Acetalization Acidity Process optimization Biomass conversion 1 Introduction Acetals are commonly used as solvents, ingredients in perfumes or flavor chemicals, and intermediates or final products in petrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, and fine chemicals processes [1–3]. As carbonyl derivatives, acetals are excellent protection groups for carbonyl groups during multistep organic synthesis mainly due to their stability and lack of reactivity in basic media. Conventionally, acetalization reactions are catalyzed by liquid acids such as H2SO4, HCl, H3PO4, p-toluenesulfonic acid (in toluene), or acidic ionic liquids (ILs) [4–9], which are handicapped by undesirable environmental hazards due to their high corrosiveness and formidable recovery and reuse. In addition, acetalization carried out over these acid catalysts also suffered from inherent problems such as highly susceptible to water and excessive amounts of by-products. As such, considerable efforts have been made in developing more durable solid acid catalysts for acetalization of aldehyde with alcohol, for examples, supported Lewis acid [10–12], zeolites [13,14], montmorillonites [5,15], and ion exchange resins [16–18]. Nonetheless, issues related to product selectivity, environmental safety, spent catalyst disposal, and catalyst recyclability remained as critical challenges for the design and fabrication of highly active catalysts for acetalization. Heteropolyacids (HPAs), especially those of the Keggin series, have been widely used as catalysts in heterogeneous as well as homogeneous reactions for the synthesis of fine and/or special chemicals due to their unique structural, redox, and acidic properties [19–24]. However, despite of their strong acidic characteristics, HPAs are often limited by the low thermal stability, inferior solubility in polar solvents, and small surface area (<10m2/g). The latter largely inhibits accessibility of internal active sites from reactants during the catalytic reaction. To circumvent this problem, modified catalysts such as HPAs supported on porous substrates have been employed [25–27]. However, inevitable catalyst leaching usually takes place, especially for catalysts prepared by incorporating HPAs onto the supports by physisorption, leading to formidable problems in separation, recovery, and recycling of the catalyst. Thus, the development of durable HPA-based catalysts with facile recovery should be highly desirable; a task this study aims to explore. Moreover, considerable R&D attentions have been paid in practical applications of ionic liquids (ILs) for organic reactions owing to their tailorable physicochemical properties, excellent thermal stability, and durability [9,28–30]. Consisting of an organic cation and an inorganic anion via ionic linkage, the structural properties of ILs may be modified by altering the inorganic anions [31], forming unique organic-inorganic hybrid materials [32]. Such materials are anticipated to possess high melting point, low solubility in common organic solvents, and high mass transfer resistance [33], which are favorable as designed acid catalysts for organic reactions [32,34–37]. We report herein the physicochemical and catalytic properties of a series of Keggin-type tungstophosphoric acid (TPA)-base IL salts prepared via ionic linkage of the polyanions of TPA with an imidazolium-based zwitterionic precursor, namely pyridinium propyl sulfobetaine (PPS), under varied composition ratios. The acid properties of the PPS-TPA IL catalysts so prepared were characterized by solid-state 31P magic-angle-spinning (MAS) NMR using the adsorbed trialkylphosphine oxide (TMPO) as the probe molecule [38–45]. Moreover, their catalytic activities during acetalization of benzaldehyde with glycol were also investigated; the corresponding reaction process and product optimizations were accomplished by a factorial experimental design and response surface methodology (RSM) [46–48]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The PPS-TPAs IL catalysts were prepared following the procedures outlined in the literature (see Scheme S1; Supplementary data) [32,49]. In brief, known amounts of 1,3-propane sultone (12.2g, 0.1mol) was first mixed with pyridine (7.91g, 0.1mol) under stirring condition at 80°C for about 6–12h. Then, the solid zwitterion mass was filtered and washed thrice with ethyl acetate, followed by drying under vacuum (≤76Torr). Subsequently, an aqueous solution of TPA (H3PW12O40; 5.76g in 50mL H2O) was added, and the mixture was stirred at 90°C for 24h. After removal of water, the final product was washed with diethyl ether, and then dried under vacuum. A series of PPS-TPA IL salts so prepared with varied PPS/TPA ratios are denoted as [PPSH] x H3−x PW12O40; x =1.0–3.0. All research grade chemicals were used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst characterization All Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded in 4000–400cm−1 region on a Bruker IFS-28 spectrometer. A KBr disk was used to mount the sample. Thermogravimetric and differential thermogravimetric analysis (TGA–DTG) analyses were obtained on a TG-209 (Netzsch) apparatus. Typically, each sample was heated from room temperature (RT; 25°C) to 600°C at a heating rate of 10K/min under dynamic N2 atmosphere. All NMR spectra were acquired on an Avance III 500 (Bruker-Biospin) spectrometer using a single-pulse sequence and operating at a Larmor frequency of 500.13, 125.76, and 202.46MHz for the 1H, 13C, and 31P nucleus, respectively. All [PPSH] x H3−x PW12O40 (x =1.0–3.0) IL catalysts exhibited similar high-resolution (solution-state) 1H and 13C NMR spectra in D2O. As an illustration, the NMR data obtained from the [PPSH]2.0HPW12O40 catalyst are listed below: 1H NMR (500MHz, D2O); δ 2.482 (t, 2H), 2.982 (t, 2H), 4.825 (t, 2H), 8.220 (t, 2H), 8.705 (t, 1H), 8.878 (d, 2H) ppm; 13C NMR (500MHz, D2O); δ 26.43, 47.29, 60.27, 129.04, 144.32, 146.42ppm. On the other hand, detailed acid features, namely relative concentration and strength of Brønsted acidity in the PPS-TPA IL catalysts were studied by solid-state 31P magic-angle-spinning (MAS) NMR of the adsorbed trimethylphosphine oxide (TMPO) as the probe molecule [38–45]. It has been demonstrated that a linear correlation between the observed 31P NMR chemical shifts and the strengths of Brønsted acidity may be inferred [50,51] by means of such 31P-TMPO NMR approach. Prior to the adsorption of TMPO, catalyst was first subjected to a thorough dehydration treatment at 150°C for 24h under vacuum (<10−5 Torr). Subsequently, a known amount of TMPO dissolved in anhydrous CH2Cl2 was introduced into a vessel containing the dehydrated solid sample in a glove box under N2 environment. The sealed sample vessel was then connected to a vacuum manifold, followed by removal of the CH2Cl2 solvent by evacuation at 50°C. To ensure a uniform adsorption of adsorbate probe molecules in the substrate, the sample was further subjected to thermal treatment at 120°C for at least 24h. Finally, the sealed sample vessel was placed in a N2 glove box where the TMPO-loaded sample was transferred into a MAS rotor and then sealed by a gas-tight Kel-F cap. Typically, free induction decay (FID) signals were acquired using a single-pulse sequence (with a π/6 pulse-width of 1.5μs and a recycle delay of 10s) under a sample spinning rate of 12kHz. The 31P chemical shifts were referenced to 85% H3PO4 aqueous solution. 2.3 Catalytic reaction The catalytic activities of the pristine TPA and various PPS-TPA IL catalysts were examined by acetalization of benzaldehyde with glycol. Typically, research grade benzaldehyde (10.6g, 0.1mol), glycol (11.16g, 0.18mol), and the PPS-TPA IL catalyst (0.53g) were put in a three-neck flask equipped with a thermometer, a water segregator, a reflux condense, and a magnetic stirrer. The reaction mixture was heated to reflux for a desirable period of time in an oil bath under mechanical stirring, then, cooled to RT. Subsequently, owing to the self-separation characteristics of the reaction system, the precipitated IL catalyst may easily be separated, followed by filtering and washing (with diethyl ether) for later recycle use. Chemical analysis of the products was performed by a gas chromatograph (GC; Agilent 6890N) equipped with a FID detector and an HP-5 capillary column. Reactants and products were identified by comparing with authentic samples by using biphenyl as the internal standard. The yield was determined by the weight of acetal distilled at a specific temperature range of ca. 224–228°C from the products. 2.4 Design of experiments and response surface methodology (RSM) Response surface methodology (RSM) was employed to optimize the reaction process and product yield during acetalization of benzaldehyde with glycol over the PPS-TPA IL catalysts on the basis of a Box–Behnken experimental design [46]. The design of experiments include four experimental variables specified in Table 1 , namely reaction time (x 1), alcohol/aldehyde reactant ratio (x 2), water-carrying agent amount (x 3), and catalyst amount (x 4). According, a 34 full-factorial central composite design with coded levels (see Table 1) was used, leading to a total of 29 experimental sets, which include 24 factorial points and 5 centering points. The aforementioned four experimental variables were tested at levels coded with either a minus sign (−1; lower value), zero (0; central value), or a plus sign (+1; higher value). The Design-Expert 6.0.5 (Stat-Ease, USA) software was used for the design of experiments and analyses of experimental data. The coded values of these factors were obtained by the equation [46]: (1) x i = X i − X 0 Δ X i where x i , X i , and X 0 (i =1–4) represents the coded, real, and central value of the independent variable, respectively, and ΔX i denotes the step change value. A model equation based on second-degree polynomial given by RSM was used to reveal the interactive effects between experimental variables to optimize the reaction process, and to predict the yield of primary product (i.e., benzaldehyde glycol acetal), which represents the response of the experimental design. The quadratic equation model may be expressed as: (2) Y = β 0 + ∑ i = 1 k β i x i + ∑ i = 1 k β i i x i 2 + ∑ j = 1 k β i j x i x i j + ε where Y is the predicted response (product yield); β o , β i , β ii , and β ij denote the regression coefficients representing the offset term, main, quadratic, and interaction effects, respectively; k is the total number of designed variables; ɛ represents the random error. Accordingly, the fitted polynomial equation may further be expressed in terms of response surface and contour plots to facilitate visualization of the correlations between the response and experimental variables at various coded levels, and to infer optimized process conditions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts Fig. 1 displays the FT-IR spectra of the pristine TPA (i.e., H3PW12O40) and its organic salt derivatives PPS-TPA (i.e., [PPSH] x H3−x PW12O40; x =1.0–3.0) IL. The IR spectrum of pristine TPA (Fig. 1a) showed characteristic bands at 1080, 981, 896, and 806cm−1 anticipated for the Keggin structure, and may be attributed to asymmetric stretching vibrations of PO, terminal WO, corner-sharing WOb W, and edge-sharing WOc W bonds, respectively [25]. Upon incorporating TPA onto PPS, catalyst samples prepared with varied PPS/TPA molar ratios exhibited additional bands at 680, 1223, and 1189cm−1, which may be assigned to CH bending vibrations in the pyridine fragment, and asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of SO, respectively (Fig. 1b–f) [32]. Moreover, regardless of the slight shifts in frequencies and decreases in peak intensities, the aforementioned four characteristic bands remained visible in all PPS-TPA IL catalysts, indicating the preservation of Keggin structure even after partial substitution of protons in TPA by organic [PPSH]+ cations. These observations verify the successful linkage between the sulfonate functionalized organic cations and the inorganic polyanions (PW12O40 3−; PW). Thermal analysis (TGA–DTG) was employed to investigate the thermal stability of the [PPSH] x H3−x PW12O40 IL catalysts. Since most PPS-TPA IL catalysts were found to exhibit similar thermal properties, herein, only the TGA–DTG curve of the [PPSH]2HPW12O40 (x =2.0) sample is illustrated and discussed. As shown in Fig. 2a, while the parent PPS exhibited only a weight-loss peak at 320°C, the pristine TPA showed three major peaks at 73, 195, and 530°C (Fig. 2b), which may be ascribed to desorption of physisorbed water, loss of crystalline water, and collapse of Keggin structure, respectively. By comparison, more complex profile was observed for the [PPSH]2HPW12O40 IL catalyst (Fig. 2c). In addition to the weight-loss peaks associated with TPA, additional peaks centered at 70, 150, 280, and 465°C are visible. While the weight loss at 280°C may be unambiguously attributed to decomposition of the organic PPS (Fig. 2a), the former two peaks at 70 and 150°C may be due to desorption of physisorbed water and dehydration of relatively stable hydrates, respectively, while the latter peak at 465°C may be arising from collapse of Keggin structure. Thus, results obtained from thermal analysis further demonstrated that PW anions were indeed successfully anchored on the PPS, and remained stable within the temperature range employed during the catalytic reaction. Solid-state 31P MAS NMR of adsorbed trialkylphosphine oxides (R3PO) has been shown to be a unique and powerful technique for acidic characterization of solid acid catalysts [38–45]. Among R3PO probe molecules, trimethylphosphine oxide (TMPO) being a suitable size (kinetic diameter 0.55nm) is commonly used [40–42]. As demonstrated in our earlier reports, interactions between the TMPO probe molecule and protic (Brønsted) acid sites promote the formation of TMPOH+ complexes, which gives rise to 31P resonances with chemical shifts (CSs) typically within the range of 50 to 95ppm, whereas physisorbed TMPO appears at ca. 35–45ppm [38–42]. Furthermore, a linear correlation exists between the 31P NMR CS (δ31P) of the adsorbed TMPO and proton affinity (PA) value (also known as deprotonation energy, i.e., energy required to remove a hydrogen ion (H+) from a Brønsted acid site); as verified by density functional theory (DFT) theoretical calculations [50,51]. Thus, a higher observed δ31P value of the adsorbed TMPO would correspond to Brønsted acid sites with stronger acidic strength, and vice versa. Moreover, the peak areas of the 31P NMR resonances may be correlated with relative acid concentrations. Fig. 3 shows the 31P MAS NMR spectra of TMPO adsorbed on pristine TPA and various [PPSH] x H3−x W12O40 IL samples obtained with a fixed guest molecule loading (ca. 3.0 TMPO molecules per Keggin unit of TPA). The 31P spectrum of the pristine TPA in Fig. 3a exhibited multiple resonances. The sharp peaks at ca. −10.8 and −15.0ppm may be unambiguously attributed to 31P resonance of the PW Keggin framework [52,53], peaks at ca. 82.2, 88.6, and 92.2ppm should arise from TMPO adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites of the TPA with different acidic strengths. That the δ31P values observed for such TMPOH+ adsorption complexes are in the proximity of the threshold value predicted for superacidity (86ppm) [38,39,50,51], indicates that the parent H3PW12O40 catalyst indeed possesses ultra-strong acidity. Moreover, additional resonance peaks were also observed with δ31P within the range of 55–80ppm, which may be attributed to the presence of (TMPO)2H+ adducts, i.e., the absorption of two TMPO molecules per protic site [52]. In addition to the sharper peaks arising from the PW anions, broadening of 31P resonances responsible for the TMPOH+ and (TMPO)2H+ adducts were evident upon anchoring TPA onto PPS, leading to two broad peaks centering at δ31P ca. 84.4 and 66.4ppm, respectively (Fig. 3b–f). By comparison, the parent PPS exhibited only a single sharp peak at 42.1ppm, which is mostly arising from physisorbed TMPO (Fig. 3g) [38–42]. This indicates that PPS possesses very weak acidity at ambient temperature. Moreover, the peak intensities associated with various [PPSH] x H3−x PW12O40 IL catalysts were found to decrease with increasing x value. Clearly, incorporation of PPS tends to provoke an effective averaging of Brønsted acid strengths, and results in lowering of the overall acidity. Moreover, a progressive decrease in acid concentration with increasing PPS/TPA ratio may be inferred from the peak intensities (areas) of the two main 31P resonances. It is anticipated that an increasing incorporation of PPS not only facilitates the elimination of available protic sites but also promotes segregation of PW polyanions, which is favorable for molecular transport. Similar phenomenon was also observed during esterification of palmitic acid with ethanol to biodiesel over TPA-based 3-(1-methylimidazolium-3-yl) propane-1-sulfonate ([MIM-PSH] x H3−x PW12O40) ionic liquid catalysts [53]. 3.2 Acetalization of benzaldehyde with glycol Catalytic activities of the pristine TPA and various PPS-TPA IL catalysts were investigated for acetalization, which is known to be a typical acid-catalyzed reaction. It is noteworthy that, the water soluble [PPSH] x H3−x PW12O40 IL catalysts tend to dissolve completely in the reaction medium, forming a homogeneous system during the initial stage of the reaction. However, the system gradually became turbid milky at prolonged reaction time and the PPS-TPA IL catalysts eventually precipitate upon completion of acetalization reaction. Such a reaction induced self-separation catalytic system [32,54], which enhances the spontaneous formation of products-catalyst (liquid-colloid) biphasic layers, readily facilitate separation of products as well as recovery and recycling of catalysts. Similar results have also been found in esterification reaction over polyoxometalate-based sulfonated ionic liquid catalysts [32,34,55,56]. Nevertheless, unlike [PPSH] x H3−x PW12O40 IL catalysts (with x =1.0–3.0) report herein, the protic sites in heteropolyacids of aforementioned catalysts were completely substituted by organic [PPSH]+ cations (i.e., comparable to the case of [PPSH]3.0PW12O40 with x =3.0 herein). It is noteworthy that the [PPSH] x H3−x PW12O40 IL catalysts so synthesized herein are highly soluble in water and/or strong polar solvents but immiscible with apolar ethers. Thus, the reaction system is strictly homogeneous at the early stage of acetalization reaction due to complete dissolution of the PPS-TPA IL catalyst in polyols and water. As the reaction proceeded, progressive consumption of reactants (polyols) will be accompanied by progressive yield of products (acetals), leading to quasi-equilibrium state of turbid fluid. Upon completion of the acetalization reaction, the mixture was cooled to room temperature. The presence of acetal and water-carrying agent (cyclohexane) help to provoke self-separation of the reaction mixture into biphasic layers. The upper layer acetal products may facilely be withdrawn while the precipitated PPS-TPA IL catalyst at the bottom layer can be recycled after simple filtering or centrifuging and washing treatments. The catalytic performances of various catalysts during acetalization of benzaldehyde with glycol are summarized in Table 2 . Owing to their strong acidity characteristics, the PPS-TPA IL catalysts yielded anticipated high activities in the following order: [PPSH]2HPW12O40 >[PPSH]2.5H0.5PW12O40 >H3PW12O40 >[PPSH]1.5H1.5PW12O40 >[PPSH]3PW12O40 >[PPSH]H2PW12O40. As mention above, the presence of PPS, though tends to eliminate the available protic sites from TPA, it also serves as a spacer to promote segregation of PW polyanions, thus, favoring mass transport during acetalization. While PPS itself is a weak acid system (cf. Fig. 3g), which is inferior for catalyzing acetalization reaction, it tends to form PPSH+ complexes with Brønsted acid protons when in the presence of TPA (Scheme S1; Supplementary data). Together with the Brønsted acid H+, the PPSH+ complexes also serve to balance the charge of the PW polyanions. Pristine TPA, though exhibits the highest acidic strength (cf. Fig. 3a), it is handicapped by the transport resistance. As such, the three available Brønsted acid protons (H+) may not be fully accessible to the reactants during acetalization reaction, leading to a modest catalytic activity. Upon progressive incorporation of PPS, while a notable decrease in overall acidic strength of acid sites were evident (Fig. 3b–f), a progressive increase in catalytic activity due to enhancement in diffusivities of reactants and products, reaching an optimal acetal yield over the [PPSH] x H3−x PW12O40 IL catalyst with x =2.0. However, further increase in PPS/TPA ratio not only result in notable decrease in overall acid concentrations, but also lowering of molecule diffusivity, as reflected by the progressive decrease in catalytic acidity over PPS-TPA IL catalysts with x >2.0. The catalytic activities observed for these TPA-based IL catalysts should also rely on the “pseudo liquid” nature of HPAs, rendering permeation of polar substrates into their structure, and hence accelerating mass transfer [57–62]. In this work, the [PPSH]2HPW12O40 IL catalyst was found to exhibit the best catalytic activity with 85.0% acetal yield. By comparison, the pristine TPA is less appealing, although it also showed a satisfactory acetal yield (78.5%), the lack of self-separation capability (particularly in presence of excessive amount of glycol) made product separation and catalyst recovery rather difficult. Since acetalization is a reversible reaction, it is prerequisite to operate under excessive amount of one of the reactants in order to shift the reaction toward production of acetal. In this work, an excessive amount of glycol was always introduced over benzaldehyde to favor catalyst solubility during the reaction. Furthermore, since water is inevitably formed during acetalization, continuous removal of water during reaction process would be highly desirable to warrant a high acetal yield. In this regard, we used cyclohexane as the water-carrying agent. Again, the [PPSH]2HPW12O40 IL catalyst was chosen for optimization of various reaction parameters. In particular, the effects of reaction time (x 1), glycol/aldehyde molar ratio (x 2; i.e., alcohol/benzaldehyde ratio), amount of water-carrying agent (x 3; i.e., amount of cyclohexane), and amount of catalyst (x 4; i.e. amount of PPS-TPA IL) were investigated over various ranges. The corresponding symbols for experimental variables and respective coded levels representing various parameter ranges are summarized in Table 1. Accordingly, an optimal catalytic activity corresponding to an acetal yield of ca. 85% was observed for the [PPSH]2HPW12O40 IL catalyst with level 0, that is, under the conditions: x 1 =3.0h, x 2 =1.8mol/mol, x 3 =12mL, and x 4 =5wt%, as depicted in Fig. 4a–d, respectively. 3.3 Process and product optimizations A factorial design of experiments and response surface methodology (RSM) were adopted to evaluate the interactive effects of the experimental variables and to optimize the reaction process and acetal yield during acetalization of benzaldehyde with glycol [46–48]. Following the symbols and coded levels summarized in Table 1, experimental and calculated results obtained by using the designed experiments based on a Box-Behnken second-degree polynomial model are summarized in Table 3 . Accordingly, through multiple regression analysis, the yield of acetal expressed in terms of fitted results may be expressed as: (3) Y = 85.00 + 1.52 x 1 + 0.62 x 2 + 1.46 x 3 + 1.60 x 4 − 1.90 x 1 x 2 − 0.08 x 1 x 3 + 0.15 x 1 x 4 + 0.78 x 2 x 3 − 0.77 x 2 x 4 − 1.42 x 3 x 4 + 4.70 x 1 2 − 3.91 2 2 − 5.77 x 3 2 − 5.01 x 4 2 where x 1, x 2, x 3, and x 4 represent the aforementioned experimental variables (see Table 1) and Y denotes the response for acetal yield (in%). Note that in Eq. (3) above, a positive sign (+) in front of a term exemplifies the existence of a synergistic effect between the designated variables, whereas a negative sign (−) represents an antagonistic effect. The fitting quality of the quadratic model was verified by the standard analysis of variance (ANOVA) shown in Table 4 . Among them, the probability (P-value) obtained is commonly used as a scale for evaluating the significance of variables. The smaller the P-value is, the more significant is the corresponding coefficient term. As listed in Table 4, the fitting of the overall model was significant with a F-statistic value of 32.69 and a P-value less than 0.0001 at 1% confidence level for the prediction of acetal yield, revealing that the chosen model (Eq. (3)) was indeed highly reliable with a satisfactory correlation coefficient square (R 2) value of 0.9703 and an adjusted correlation coefficient (R 2 adj) of 0.9406. Furthermore, a significantly high adequate precision value of 19.93 (which is much greater than 4.0) and a relatively low coefficient of variation (CV) value of 1.38% were also deduced, indicating that an adequate signal-to-noise ratio prevailed for the model and the fitting was reproducible. Moreover, a relatively low ‘Lack of Fit’ F-value of 1.76 was observed, implying that the model indeed fitted to all data. The influence of each independent variable on the fitting model may be examined by analyzing the variances at its corresponding levels. As listed in Table 4, the P-values derived from ANOVA such as reaction time (x 1), water-carrying agent amount (x 3), and catalyst amount (x 4) were lower than 0.01, indicating that these variables have significant effect on acetal yield during acetalization reaction. In this regard, the glycol/benzaldehyde molar ratio (x 2) showed a relatively weaker influence on acetal yield. Based on the predicted model, three-dimensional (3D) response surface plots (Fig. S1; Supplementary data) as well as their corresponding contour plots (Fig. S2; Supplementary data) representing correlations between each pair of two experimental variables (while keeping other variables at their respective level of zero; see Table 1) may be obtained. For correlations between reaction time (x 1) and glycol/benzaldehyde ratio (x 2) on acetal yield, the x 1 x 2 influence was highly significant with a fairly low P-value of 0.0031. Apparently, x 1 has a stronger influence than x 2. At a given glycol/benzaldehyde ratio, the acetal yield was found to increase with reaction time at first, reaching a maximum at x 1 =3.0h (level 0; Table 1), then decline with x 1. The latter decline in acetal yield with increasing reaction time is most likely due to the progressive increase in by-products. On the other hand, a moderate change in acetal yield with x 2 was observed at a constant x 1. These results are in agreement with the data given in Table 1. For correlations between x 1 and x 3 on acetal yield, the x 1 x 3 influence was found less significant with a P-value of 0.8900 (Table 3). This indicates that no serious interactions between reaction time and amount of cyclohexane (as the water-carrying agent) can be inferred. Likewise, similar conclusions may be drawn for the x 1 x 4, x 2 x 3, and x 2 x 4 correlations on acetal yield, corresponding to an inferior P-value of 0.7823, 0.1676, and 0.1676, respectively. Thus, while x 1, x 3, and x 4 exhibited highly significant influence on acetal yield individually (with P-value much smaller than 0.01; Table 3), mutual correlations between each pair of variables showed no significant influence on acetal yield, except for the x 1 x 2 (vide supra) and the x 3 x 4 correlations. The latter with a fair deduced P-value of 0.0181 revealed that correlation between the amount of water-carrying agent and the amount of PPS-TPA IL catalyst have some impacts on the acetal yield. Based on RSM results obtained from all 29 experimental sets, the optimal process conditions deduced for the [PPSH]2HPW12O40 IL catalyst during acetalization of benzaldehyde with glycol are the following: x 1 =3.08h (reactant time), x 2 =1.81 (glycol/benzaldehyde molar ratio), x 3 =12.22mL (amount of cyclohexane as water-carrying agent), and x 4 =5.14wt% (amount of PPS-TPA IL catalyst), leading to a predicted optimal acetal yield of 85.32%. To confirm the validity of the model and optimal process conditions, four additional experiments were conducted in parallel with x 1 =3.1h, x 2 =1.8, x 3 =12.2mL, and x 4 =5wt%. Accordingly, an average experimental acetal yield of 85.2% was obtained, in excellent agreement with the predicted value. 3.4 Stability test As mentioned earlier, one of the major advantages of the PPS-TPA IL catalysts studied herein is their feasibility for separation and recycling. As an illustration, the stability of the [PPSH]2HPW12O40 IL catalyst was investigated. The stability tests were conducted by extracting the catalyst from the system after each run, washed with diethyl ether, followed by drying under vacuum for 10h at 70°C before repeated use. Accordingly, the acetal yields obtained after consecutive cycles under the aforementioned conditions are shown in Fig. 5 . After six consecutive runs, a slight decrease in acetal yield from 85.2% of the initial run to 77.8% due to deactivation was observed. The observed marginal loss (ca. 8.7%) in acetal yield indicates that the PPS-TPA ILs so prepared are indeed highly acidic and stable catalysts desirable for acetalization of aldehydes with alcohols. 4 Conclusions A series of heteropolyacid-based ionic liquid catalysts, [PPSH] x H3−x PW12O40 (x =1.0–3.0), were successfully prepared and employed for acetalization of benzaldehyde with glycol. The acid properties of the synthesized PPS-TPA IL catalysts were characterized by solid-state 31P MAS NMR of adsorbed trimethylphosphine oxide (TMPO) as the probe molecule. The [PPSH]2HPW12O40 catalyst, which showed optimal catalytic performance, was exploited for process optimization. A factorial design of experiments has been used to predict the catalytic activity and to reveal correlations among various experimental variables. As a result, a high acetal yield of 85.2% was achieved with optimized experimental parameters: reactant time=3.1h, amount of water-carrying agent=12.2mL, glycol/benzaldehyde ratio=1.8, and amount of catalyst=5wt%, which are in agreement with experimental values. Further stability study revealed that these catalysts not only possess desirable self-separation characteristics but also recyclability during acetalization. Thus, these heteropolyacid-based ionic liquids are effective catalysts for the synthesis of benzaldehyde glycol acetal, and have potential applications for industrial production of acetal. coredata.dc:description: A series of environmental benign ionic liquid (IL) catalysts, synthesized by incorporating varied amounts of tungstophosphoric acid (TPA) and pyridinium propyl sulfobetaine (PPS) zwitterionic precursor, were exploited for homogeneous conversion of biomass. In particular, these water-soluble PPS-TPA IL ([PPSH] x H3−x PW12O40; x =1.0–3.0) catalysts were evaluated for acetalization of benzaldehyde with glycol. The catalyst system revealed self-separation characteristics, which resulted in the formation of biphasic product/catalyst layers to render facile product separation and catalyst recycling. Among various PPS-TPA ILs examined, the [PPSH]2HPW12O40 catalyst exhibited excellent durability and an optimal acetal yield over 85%, in good agreement with that predicted by factorial design of experiments and response surface methodology (RSM). The effects and correlations of different experimental variables such as reaction time, relative reactant concentration, amount of water-carrying agent, and amount of catalyst were addressed by the Box–Behnken design (BBD). The deduced optimal conditions lead to an acetal yield of 85.2%, which is consistent with experimental results and that predicted by the BBD model. The superior acetalization activities observed for the novel PPS-TPA IL catalysts are attributed to their highly acidic nature and weak mass transport resistance.
coredata.dc:title: Heteropolyacid-based ionic liquids as effective catalysts for the synthesis of benzaldehyde glycol acetal
